Shortcuts

Generate LaTeX from CBD Models¶

A module that allows the construction of LaTeX-equations from a CBD model, as a whole (one equation per block and per connection) or as a simplified version (by means of substitution).

class CBD.converters.latexify.CBD2Latex(model, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

Creates a corresponding set of LaTeX-equations for a CBD model.

Parameters:

model (CBD.Core.CBD) – The model to create the equations for.
Keyword Arguments:
 
  • show_steps (bool) – When True, all intermediary steps will be shown. Defaults to False.
  • ignore_path (bool) – When True, the name of the original model will be removed from all path names. This name is a common prefix over the system. Defaults to True.
  • escape_nonlatex (bool) – When True, non-latex characters are escaped from the rendered result. Defaults to True.
  • time_variable (str) – The name for the variable that represents the time (i.e., the current iteration). Defaults to 'i'.
  • render_latex (bool) – When True, the render() method will output a latex-formatted string. Otherwise, simple text formatting is done. Defaults to True.
  • time_format (str) – How the time must be formatted when rendered. By default, it will be placed in parentheses at the end. Use {time} to identify the time constant.
  • delta_t (str) – Representation of the used delta in the render. This will be appended to values that have been computed for a delay block. This is only to be used when the time does not identify the iteration, but the actual simulation time. Defaults to the empty string.
  • replace_par (bool) – When True, the parentheses will be replaced by the much cleaner \left( and \right), if rendered in LaTeX-format. Defaults to True.
  • type_formats (dict) – A dictionary of { operationType -> callable } that allows for the remapping of mathematical descriptions based, where operationType identifies the operation to remap and callable a function that takes the name/symbol and the arguments as input and produces a string representation.
  • path_sep (str) – The separator to use for the paths. Defaults to ".".
  • merge_sums (bool) – Whether or not multiple additions of the same sub-equation should be merged into a product. Defaults to True.
  • merge_prods (bool) – Whether or not multiple products of the same sub-equation should be merged into a power. Defaults to True.
  • merge_negs (bool) – Whether or not all negations in a product should be merged into a single negation. Defaults to True.
DEFAULT_CONFIG = {'delta_t': '', 'escape_nonlatex': True, 'ignore_path': True, 'merge_negs': True, 'merge_prods': True, 'merge_sums': True, 'path_sep': '.', 'render_latex': True, 'replace_par': True, 'show_steps': False, 'time_format': '({time})', 'time_variable': 'i', 'type_formats': {}}¶

Default configuration setup.

static rename(name, config, model)[source]¶

Makes the name of a path accurate.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – The name to convert.
  • config (dict) – Configuration dictionary (see above).
  • model (CBD) – The parent CBD model.
static get_block_data(block, model, conf=None)[source]¶
render(rl=True)[source]¶

Creates the LaTeX string for the model, based on the current level of simplifications.

Parameters:rl (bool) – Identifies if the rendering must result in a LaTeX-renderable string. This argument basically overwrites the render_latex config attribute. When None, the value from the config is used. Defaults to True.
eq()[source]¶

Obtains the current set of equations in a format that can be parsed by the CBD.converters.eq2CBD converter. This allows model simplifications and optimizations.

create_ic()[source]¶

Creates the equations for the initial conditions of a system.

simplify_links()[source]¶

First step to execute is a link simplification. Generally, there are more links than blocks, so this function will take care of the largest simplification.

substitute()[source]¶

Combines multiple equations into one, based on the requested output, by means of substitution. This function will be called multiple times: once for each “step” in the simplification.

See also

simplify()

get_dependencies_for(variable, visited=())[source]¶

Tries to obtain all dependencies of a specific variable, to prevent accidental removal. This will be done via a depth-first search.

Parameters:
  • variable (str) – The variable to get the dependencies for.
  • visited (iter) – A collection of all variables that have been checked.
simplify(steps=-1)[source]¶

Simplifies the system of equations to become a more optimal solution.

Parameters:steps (int) – When positive, this indicates the amount of steps that must be taken. When negative, the equations will be simplified until a convergence (i.e. no possible changes) is reached. Defaults to -1.

See also

  • simplify_links()
  • substitute()
class CBD.converters.latexify.Fnc(name, args, fmt=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

An identifier of a function within the context of the equation system. This class is a helper class to be used by the CBD2Latex class.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – The name of the function.
  • args (list) – The ordered list of arguments to be applied by the function.
  • fmt – A function that takes a name/symbol and a set of arguments, allowing it to return a custom string representation for the given function. When None, the default representation will be used.
apply(name, value)[source]¶

Recursively replaces all references of a variable by its value.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – The variable to replace.
  • value – The value to replace the variable by.
apply_delay(time=-1)[source]¶

Applies a delay to the function and all its children. Can be used to remove delays from the system.

Calling apply_time() followed by apply_delay() with the same time solves the system for that time.

Parameters:time (int) – The time whence to apply the delay.
simplify(merge_sums, merge_prods, merge_negs)[source]¶

Simplifies the function w.r.t. its meaning.

Parameters:
  • merge_sums (bool) – Whether or not multiple additions of the same sub-equation should be merged into a product.
  • merge_prods (bool) – Whether or not multiple products of the same sub-equation should be merged into a power.
  • merge_negs (bool) – Whether or not all negations in a product should be merged into a single negation.
is_numeric()[source]¶

Checks if the function only contains numeric arguments.

dependencies()[source]¶

Obtains the dependencies for executing the function.

brackets()[source]¶

Tests if it is required to enclose the function in brackets.

latex(latex=True, time_var='i')[source]¶

Returns a LaTeX-formatted string of this function.

Parameters:
  • latex (bool) – Whether or not to use LaTeX-based strings.
  • time_var (str) – The time var string name to use for complex math.
apply_time(time=0, t='t', fmt='({time})', dt='')[source]¶

Converts all equations to functions that take a time-argument. Delay blocks decrease the “time” annotation. This function is used to find the initial conditions of a system.

Calling apply_time() followed by apply_delay() with the same time solves the system for that time.

Parameters:
  • time (int) – How much time in the past this must be applied. A positive value of n means this is applied at time-n.
  • t (str/int) – The time variable name, or an integer indicative of a specific time that must be applied. E.g., setting this value to 2 will apply the the formulas at time 2.
  • fmt (str) – The format for the time. By default it will be placed in parentheses at the end. Use {time} to identify the time variable.
  • dt (str) – The representation of the used delta. This will be appended after the n value. Defaults to the empty string.
get_delay_depth(start=0)[source]¶

Counts the amount of “nested” delay blocks.

Parameters:start (int) – Initial count value.
